Based on my search results, I can confirm several key facts about T.S. Eliot's rejection letter of George Orwell's Animal Farm:

## Verification of the Letter

The letter was indeed written by T.S. Eliot on July 13, 1944, when he was a director at publishing firm Faber & Faber, addressed to "Dear Orwell". The British Library has digitized this rejection letter, confirming its authenticity and preservation in their archives.

## The "Public-Spirited Pigs" Quote

The famous quote about "public-spirited pigs" appears in the letter exactly as referenced. Eliot wrote: "And after all, your pigs are far more intelligent than the other animals, and therefore the best qualified to run the farm—in fact, there couldn't have been an Animal Farm at all without them: so that what was needed, (someone might argue), was not more communism but more public-spirited pigs."

## Context of the Rejection

Eliot acknowledged the quality of the work, stating: "We agree that it is a distinguished piece of writing; that the fable is very skilfully handled, and that the narrative keeps one's interest on its own plane – and that is something very few authors have achieved since Gulliver."

However, Eliot's main reason for rejection was political: "we have no conviction (and I am sure none of the other directors would have) that this is the right point of view from which to criticise the political situation at the present time."(no content)This rejection occurred during World War II when Britain was allied with the Soviet Union against Germany, making Animal Farm's satire of Stalinism particularly controversial.

## Additional Details

Eliot somewhat distanced himself from the "public-spirited pigs" opinion by parenthetically attributing it to what "someone might argue", suggesting either diplomatic hedging or that this view was shared among the Faber & Faber directors.

Eliot also characterized Orwell's political viewpoint as "generally Trotskyite," which he found "not convincing".

The letter demonstrates how political considerations during wartime influenced publishing decisions, even when the literary merit of the work was acknowledged.
